speaker: SCRUFFY GUY
line: Look, Ben. This is what infuriates me. Don't you see? It's so painfully obvious. Why do you think our stock's in the toilet? Because you're cutting research and development in half. You've forgotten what the adventure's all about.

speaker: SUIT GUY
line: Like it or not, the industry's changing. We need to make some hard choices.

speaker: SCRUFFY GUY
line: You save your sound bite for the press.

speaker: SUIT GUY
line: Let's not relive the stockholder's meeting again.

speaker: SCRUFFY GUY
line: Don't you get it? You're killing me! You're killing my company!

speaker: SUIT GUY
line: Eurisko is not your company, Brad - - not any more. And you damn well better grow up and get used to it.

speaker: SCRUFFY GUY (BRAD WILCZEK)
line: You're going to regret this.

speaker: SUIT GUY
line: New paragraph. As I'm sure everyone on the Board will agree, Eurisko has to face head on the realities on an increasingly competitive world. Since the unfortunate departure of Brad Wilczek, I have made certain recommendations which I believe will reposition Eurisko as an industry leader. DRAKE, BENJAMIN - DATA INTERCEPT) At the top of this list, is the immediate termination of the COS project. It's disastrous performance over the past three quarters and projected losses well into 1994 leave us no other choice.

speaker: DRAKE
line: Hello? Hello!

speaker: PHONE VOICE
line: At the tone, Eastern Standard Time will be 7:35 P.M.

speaker: DRAKE
line: What the hell?

speaker: COMPUTER VOICE
line: File deleted.

speaker: JERRY
line: Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: Jerry?

speaker: JERRY
line: You're Dana Scully, right? Jerry Lamana.

speaker: MULDER
line: Jerry and I worked together in Violent Crimes.

speaker: JERRY
line: Worked together? What are you talking worked together. We were partners.

speaker: LUNCH CART GUY
line: That's $8.50, please.

speaker: MULDER
line: So, Jerry, what are you doing here?

speaker: JERRY
line: Looking for you. And I'm buying you two lunch.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, really...

speaker: JERRY
line: No, it's on me.

speaker: JERRY
line: Cause of death was electrocution.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And it wasn't accidental?

speaker: JERRY
line: It looks like some kind of elaborate booby trap, but we don't know a whole lot more. The building engineer just found him twelve hours ago.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Who's running the investigation?

speaker: JERRY
line: Do either of you know Nancy Spiller?

speaker: SCULLY
line: The forensics instructor at the Academy? We used to call her the Iron Maiden.

speaker: JERRY
line: On a good day. Well, anyway she's putting together the squad and, well, I took the liberty of mentioning your name.

speaker: MULDER
line: Look, Jerry. I'd like to help you out, but we're not on general assignment.

speaker: JERRY
line: Because of the X-Files? Look, the truth is, I could use a little help on this. I don't want to drop the ball on this one.

speaker: MULDER
line: You won't drop the ball.

speaker: JERRY
line: Drake wasn't just a CEO of a Fortune 500 company. He was a good friend of the Attorney General's. Another feather in my cap would be really nice right now, because the one I got's looking a little mangy.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, but Jerry...

speaker: JERRY
line: Look, I wouldn't ask if it wasn't important.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How come you two went your separate ways?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm a pain in the ass to work with.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Seriously.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm not a pain in the ass? We had different career goals. Jerry wanted the fifth floor.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And you?

speaker: MULDER
line: I was gunning for a basement office with no heat or windows.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I know where you ended up. What about Jerry?

speaker: MULDER
line: He ran into a little bad luck in Atlanta working hate crimes.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What kind of bad luck?

speaker: MULDER
line: He misplaced a piece of evidence, bagged and everything. Sent it to the cleaners. By the time he got it back, a federal judge had lost both his hands and his right eye.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Twenty-nine?

speaker: MULDER
line: Uh-huh.

speaker: ELEVATOR
line: Going up.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Must be for the visually impaired.

speaker: MULDER
line: How do you like that? A politically correct elevator.

speaker: ELEVATOR
line: Third floor....Fourth floor....

speaker: MULDER
line: You okay?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah. What was that?

speaker: MAN'S VOICE
line: Yes?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Hello?

speaker: MAN'S VOICE
line: Security. Who's this?

speaker: SCULLY
line: This is Agent Dana Scully.

speaker: MAN'S VOICE
line: Agent Scully, do you have a problem?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Uh, actually, I think everything's okay.

speaker: JERRY
line: Someone has tampered with the servo. They switched the ground to the negative so that when he put the key in the lock...

speaker: SCULLY
line: ...he completed the circuit.

speaker: JERRY
line: It's fused. It takes a lot of juice to melt a steel key.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And to throw a 180 pound man ten feet.

speaker: MULDER
line: The, uh, servo switch. Could it have been moved manually?

speaker: JERRY
line: We didn't find any prints in the surrounding area.

speaker: PETERSON
line: Sure it could have been switched manually. But whoever did it would have had to override the COS.

speaker: MULDR
line: What's the COS?

speaker: PETERSON
line: The central operating system. It runs the building. It regulates everything from energy output to the volume of water in each toilet flush.

speaker: JERRY
line: This is Claude Peterson. He's the building systems engineer. He discovered the body.

speaker: MULDER
line: If somebody wanted to override the COS, what would they...?

speaker: PETERSON
line: Well, first he'd have to break the access codes which, well let's just say it wouldn't be easy.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, we're going to need a list of all the people with that kind of know how.

speaker: PETERSON
line: Well, I can tell you right now it'll be a pretty short list.

speaker: MULDER
line: Would you be on it?

speaker: PETERSON
line: Me? Hey, look. I'm just a glorified building super. All I do is monitor the system. Make sure it's functioning properly. Like when I saw the overload in Mr. Drake's office.

speaker: MULDER
line: What about the phone lines? Does the COS monitor all phone calls?

speaker: PETERSON
line: Yes it does. Why?

speaker: MULDER
line: I was just wondering.

speaker: PETERSON
line: Okay, um, look. Can I go now?

speaker: JERRY
line: Yeah. Why'd you ask him about the phones?

speaker: MULDER
line: Phone's off the hook. Maybe Drake was talking to someone right before he did his Ben Franklin impersonation.

speaker: JERRY
line: Taught him everything he knows.

speaker: MULDER
line: Come in.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It's past three.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm just looking for my profile notes.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Maybe if you cleaned your desk more than once a year.

speaker: MULDER
line: They were right here. I'm telling you.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Come on. We're late.

speaker: JERRY
line: Now, there are a couple of elements for us to consider, here. Both the statistical rarity of homicidal electrocution and the complexity of the crime indicate a certain devious premeditation. After all, there are much simpler ways of killing someone. All of which leads me to believe that our guy was some kind of sociopathic game player - - maybe even a recluse since he designed a trap not only to avoid detection, but to avoid contact with the victim.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Is that your profile?

speaker: MULDER
line: Forget it, no.

speaker: JERRY
line: Drake's final phone call supports this theory.

speaker: COMPUTER VOICE
line: At the tone, Eastern Standard Time will be 7:35 P.M.

speaker: JERRY
line: Drake's estimated time of death.

speaker: AGENT SPILLER
line: Why would Drake call for the correct time just before he died?

speaker: JERRY
line: It was an incoming call. From somewhere in the Eurisko building itself. Whoever set the trap wanted to make sure that Drake took the bait.

speaker: AGENT SPILLER
line: Excellent work, Agent Lamana.

speaker: JERRY
line: Thank you.

speaker: MULDER
line: Jerry, what the hell are you doing?

speaker: JERRY
line: Hey, don't get all bent out of shape.

speaker: MULDER
line: Jerry, that was my profile.

speaker: JERRY
line: Look, I didn't think you'd mind. Anyway, they were just notes. I filled in the blanks.

speaker: MULDER
line: Jerry, you went into my office and you stole my work.

speaker: JERRY
line: Look, you're on this case â€˜cause I asked you to help me out, and you helped me out. What is the big deal.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What did he say?

speaker: MULDER
line: He apologized - in his own way.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I just got off the phone with Peterson, the systems engineer.

speaker: MULDER
line: One name? Brad Wilczek?

speaker: SCULLY
line: He said it would be a short list. And it's headline news how much this guy despised Drake.

speaker: MULDER
line: That just seems too obvious. To kill Drake would be so brazenly egomaniacal.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And fully consistent with Jerry's excellent behavioral profile.

speaker: MULDER
line: Fully.

speaker: MULDER
line: So this is what a 220 IQ and a $400 million severance settlement buys you.

speaker: WILCZEK
line: Yes?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Brad Wilczek? We're with the FBI.

speaker: WILCZEK
line: What took you guys so long. Oh, do you mind taking off your shoes?

speaker: WILCZEK
line: You can divide the computer science industry into two types of people - - neat and scruffy.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I take it Benjamin Drake fit into the first category.

speaker: WILCZEK
line: Neat people like things neat. They wear nicely pressed suits and work on surface phenomena. Things they can understand. Market shares, and third quarter profits.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And you had a different vision for the company?

speaker: WILCZEK
line: I started Eurisko out of my parents' garage. I was 22 years old. I'd just spent a year following around the Grateful Dead. You know what Eurisko means?

speaker: MULDER
line: That's from the Greek, isn't it? Um, "I learn things."

speaker: WILCZEK
line: Not exactly. It means "I discover things." Unfortunately, Ben Drake wasn't interested in discovery. He was a short-sighted, power-hungry opportunist. Let me show you something - Smart Home. From this prototype, I have access to every square foot of my house. This place is as safe as Fort Knox and as energy efficient as your average igloo. We were two years ahead of Microsoft and Cebus when Drake, in his infinite wisdom, killed the program.

speaker: MULDER
line: Mr. Wilczek, is this system related to the one in your corporate building?

speaker: WILCZEK
line: Variation on a theme.

speaker: MULDER
line: In your opinion, how many people know the system well enough to override it?

speaker: WILCZEK
line: Finally the bonus question. Not many is the answer.

speaker: MULDER
line: Could someone have hacked into the system?

speaker: WILCZEK
line: Well, not your average phone freak, that's for sure. But there's plenty of kooks out there. Data travelers, Electro wizards, techno anarchists. Anything's possible.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Could you have done it?

speaker: WILCZEK
line: Of course. I designed the system. That's why you guys are here, isn't it? I'm your logical suspect.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You don't seem too worried.

speaker: WILCZEK
line: It's a puzzle, Miss Scully, and scruffy minds like me like puzzles. We enjoy walking down unpredictable avenues of thought, turning new corners - - but as a general rule, scruffy minds don't commit murder.

speaker: SCULLY VOICE OVER
line: Some see genius as the ability to connect the unconnected -- to make juxtapositions, to see relationships where others cannot. Is Brad Wilczek a genius? I don't know. But I do know this for certain. He has a predilection for elaborate game playing. He has an intimate knowledge of the Eurisko building and he has a demonstrable motive for killing Benjamin Drake. The question remains. But if he is so clever how do we nail him? End of field journal, October 24, 1993.

speaker: "COS SCANNING
line: Scully, Dana --- Data Intercept." Camera shows that screen is now that of the COS inside the Eurisko building that we saw in the teaser.)

speaker: COS COMPUTER
line: File opened.

speaker: MULDER
line: Will you give me a second?

speaker: JERRY
line: Look, I'm here with my hat in my hand. I screwed up - - I'm sorry. What more can I say?

speaker: MULDER
line: All you had to do was ask. I would've helped you with the profile.

speaker: JERRY
line: You don't know what it's like, Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: What *what's* like?

speaker: JERRY
line: You heard about Atlanta?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yea...

speaker: JERRY
line: They got me on six month's probation. I got to file daily reports like some cherry new agent.

speaker: MULDER
line: That was bad luck. That could have happened to anybody.

speaker: JERRY
line: Not to you.

speaker: MULDER
line: Don't run yourself down, Jerry. You're a good agent. We did some good work together.

speaker: JERRY
line: Let's face it. I was tagging along.

speaker: MULDER
line: That's not how it was.

speaker: JERRY
line: How would you know, Mulder? You were too busy dazzling them up there on the high wire.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, take a look. We borrowed this from the voice biometrics lab at Georgetown. It's a computer spectrogram capable of identifying individual speech patterns. Now this is the recording the Central Operating System made of the phone call Drake received just before he died.

speaker: RECORDING
line: At the tone, Eastern Standard Time will be 7:35 p.m.

speaker: SCULLY
line: And this we spliced together from a series of lectures Brad Wilczek gave at the Smithsonian last year.

speaker: RECORDING 2
line: At the tone, Eastern Standard Time will be 7:35 p.m.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Now we'll stack them.

speaker: JERRY
line: Your saying this is the same person?

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm saying that both voices are Brad Wilczek's. He may have disguised his voice electronically, but he couldn't alter the form that is unique to his own speech patterns.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Which means that he was the one that killed Drake. He had the motive and the means. And now we have the physical evidence. Judge Benson lives in Washington Heights. I can get a warrant in less than an hour.

speaker: JERRY
line: Someone has to make sure Wilczek stays put.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'll go with you.

speaker: JERRY
line: No. Let me bring him in alone. I need this one, Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: All right.

speaker: WILCZEK
line: Come on, come on. Let me in. Damn!

speaker: GUARD
line: Mr. Wilczek!

speaker: ELEVATOR
line: Going up. Second floor...Third floor...Fourth floor...

speaker: GUARD
line: Can I help you?

speaker: JERRY
line: FBI

speaker: COMPUTER
line: Welcome back, Brad.

speaker: WILCZEK
line: You're not equipped with a voice synthesizer. What is my user level?

speaker: COMPUTER
line: That is now at the discretion of the Operating System.

speaker: ELEVATOR
line: `Going up.

speaker: WILCZEK
line: What are you doing?

speaker: COMPUTER
line: Sorry. Those commands are not available at your current user level. Try again.

speaker: WILCZEK
line: What are you doing!

speaker: COMPUTER
line: What are you doing!

speaker: JERRY
line: Oh, man.

speaker: ELEVATOR
line: Going down.

speaker: WILCZEK
line: NO!! Don't do this!

speaker: COMPUTER
line: Program executed.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I heard about Jerry. I'm sorry.

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't think Wilczek did it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What?

speaker: MULDER
line: It doesn't make sense. Why would he go back to Eurisko?

speaker: SCULLY
line: To destroy evidence. To cover his tracks.

speaker: MULDER
line: If you were going to destroy evidence, would you pose for the cameras?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, you've been through a lot - - more than I think even you realize.

speaker: MULDER
line: I think Wilczek is smarter than this.

speaker: SCULLY
line: He just signed a confession. How much proof do you need?

speaker: SUIT #1
line: Excuse me sir, this is a crime scene. You're going to have to leave.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, I know. I ordered the subpoena.

speaker: SUIT #1
line: That subpoena's been obviated.

speaker: MULDER
line: What are you talking about?

speaker: SUIT #1
line: Unless you've got a code five clearance, I'm going to have to ask you to turn back.

speaker: MULDER
line: Thanks for coming.

speaker: DEEP THROAT
line: I'm here against my better judgement. In the future I must insist that you respect the terms of our arrangement.

speaker: MULDER
line: I need to know why Brad Wilczek is the subject of a code five investigation. What the Defense Department wants with him.

speaker: DEEP THROAT
line: What do you think they'd want with the most innovative programmer in this hemisphere?

speaker: MULDER
line: Software.

speaker: DEEP THROAT
line: For years, Wilczek has thumbed his nose at any contract involving weapons applications. He's a bleeding heart.

speaker: MULDER
line: What kind of software?

speaker: DEEP THROAT
line: How much do you know about artificial intelligence?

speaker: MULDER
line: I thought it was only theoretical.

speaker: DEEP THROAT
line: It was, until two years ago. You remember Helsinki, the first time that a chess playing computer ever beat a Grand Master? That was Wilczek's program. And the rumor was that he did it by developing the first adaptive network.

speaker: MULDER
line: An adaptive network?

speaker: DEEP THROAT
line: It's a learning machine. A computer that actually thinks. And it's, ah, become something of a holy grail for some of our more acquisitive colleagues in the Department of Defense.

speaker: WILCZEK
line: They make me wear shoes all the time. What else do you want from me?

speaker: MULDER
line: I want you to tell me why you're willing to spend the rest of your life in prison for a crime you didn't commit.

speaker: WILCZEK
line: What are you talking about? I'm guilty.

speaker: MULDER
line: I know you're innocent. You're protecting a machine -- the Central Operating System at Eurisko.

speaker: WILCZEK
line: If I'm protecting anything, it's not the machine.

speaker: MULDER
line: Then what?

speaker: WILCZEK
line: After the bomb was dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki - - Robert Oppenheimer spent the rest of his life regretting he'd ever glimpsed an atom.

speaker: MULDER
line: Oppenheimer may have regretted his actions but he never denied responsibility for them.

speaker: WILCZEK
line: He loved the work, Mr. Mulder. His mistake was in sharing it with an immoral government. I won't make the same mistake.

speaker: MULDER
line: But your machine killed Drake. And it killed my friend.

speaker: WILCZEK
line: I'm sorry about what happened. But there's nothing I can do.

speaker: MULDER
line: And you talk about morality. You're afraid of the government but you're willing to accept the risk that your machine will kill again.

speaker: WILCZEK
line: The lesser of two evils.

speaker: MULDER
line: What about a third option. You created that machine. Now you tell me how to destroy it.

speaker: MULDER
line: Wilczek can create a virus that will destroy the system.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, don't you see, blaming the machine is an alibi, and a bad one.

speaker: MULDER
line: But it's the only thing that makes sense. The COS project was posting big losses for Eurisko and Drake was about to terminate the program.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So the machine killed Drake out of self-defense?

speaker: MULDER
line: Self-preservation. It's the primary instinct of all sentient beings.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, that level of artificial intelligence is decades away from being realized.

speaker: MULDER
line: Then why was our government trying to usurp Wilczek's research?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, I think you're looking for something that isn't there. And I think it has something to do with Jerry. Maybe it wouldn't be such a bad idea if you talked to someone.

speaker: MULDER
line: You're probably right.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Where are you going?

speaker: MULDER
line: To talk to someone.

speaker: MULDER
line: How much time do you need?

speaker: SCULLY ASLEEP. CLOCK 1
line: 31. Phone rings. SCULLY picks it up)

speaker: SCULLY
line: Hello?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Oh my God. This is Special Agent Dana Scully, ID number 2317-616. I need you to run a quick trace on a number for me. Yeah, 202-555-6431. Yeah, that's my number. Somebody's accessing my computer.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder!

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully, what are you doing here?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Someone or something's been scanning my computer files. Tapping my phones. I traced the line. It came from somewhere in there.

speaker: MULDER
line: It's the machine.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How can we get in?

speaker: MULDER
line: You remember the Trojan Horse?

speaker: MULDER
line: Open, Sesame!

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh, what the - -

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder!

speaker: MULDER
line: So much for the element of surprise. What do you say we take the stairs?

speaker: MULDER
line: 28 down, one to go.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Oh, great. Mulder?

speaker: MULDER
line: Trick or treat.

speaker: MULDER
line: No!

speaker: SCULLY
line: What are you doing?

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't want to make the same mistake Drake made.

speaker: MULDER
line: What are you looking at?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Unh....

speaker: MULDER
line: There should be a way for you to drop down and open the door.

speaker: MULDER
line: Come on, Scully.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully?

speaker: PETERSON
line: Agent Mulder? What are you doing here?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Ahhhhh!!!!!

speaker: PETERSON
line: The machine's been acting all crazy. Power surges, shut off. That's why I'm here so late.

speaker: MULDER
line: Where's the B port?

speaker: PETERSON
line: Oh, it's right back here. Look, are you sure you know what you're doing? Because if you don't, it's my job on the line.

speaker: MULDER
line: Damn.

speaker: COMPUTER
line: System access granted. User code level seven.

speaker: MULDER
line: Now I can put in the virus.

speaker: PETERSON
line: Not bad, Agent Mulder. You know, I've been trying to access the CPU for the past two years. Now please, take out your gun and remove the clip. Careful.

speaker: MULDER
line: Defense Department?

speaker: PETERSON
line: Lets just say our paychecks are signed by the same person. Now give me the diskette and step away from the console. You don't want to test my resolve, Agent Mulder.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Put down the gun.

speaker: PETERSON
line: Look, you may think you know what you're dealing with -

speaker: SCULLY
line: Shut up and drop the gun.

speaker: PETERSON
line: You're making a mistake, Agent Scully. Compromising your sworn duty. This operation is more sensitive than you can possibly imagine.

speaker: MULDER
line: Don't listen to him.

speaker: PETERSON
line: The technology in this machine is of enormous scientific interest.

speaker: MULDER
line: The machine's a monster, Scully. It's already killed two people. They won't be able to handle it any better than Wilczek did.

speaker: PETERSON
line: Make no mistake..... *You* will be held accountable.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, put in the disc.

speaker: COMPUTER
line: What are you doing, Brad? Don't do this, Brad. Brad....Brad....Why?

speaker: MULDER
line: I checked with Congressman Klebanon and the Department of Corrections Subcommittee. I even petitioned the Attorney General's office.

speaker: DEEP THROAT
line: You won't find him.

speaker: MULDER
line: They can't just take a man like Brad Wilczek without an explanation.

speaker: DEEP THROAT
line: *They* can do anything they want.

speaker: MULDER
line: Where is he?

speaker: DEEP THROAT
line: In the middle of what we in the trade call "hard bargaining."

speaker: MULDER
line: Wilczek won't deal. He'll never work for them.

speaker: DEEP THROAT
line: Loss of freedom does funny things to a man, and remember, Wilczek confessed to two murders, and you effectively destroyed the only evidence that could have exonerated him.

speaker: MULDER
line: What else could I have done?

speaker: DEEP THROAT
line: Nothing... Unless you were willing to let the technology survive.

speaker: MULDER
line: The Department of Defense still hasn't found anything?

speaker: DEEP THROAT
line: They've been on it for five days. Wilczek's virus was thorough. It left no trace of the artificial intelligence. The machine is dead.

speaker: PETERSON
line: We've pushed the pulse code modulations to the limit. Nothing. We've combed the parsing subroutine. Yes, sir. Twice. No, sir. Still nothing. But I'd like to request.... Yes, sir. No, I understand. Yes, sir. Well, six more hours before we have to consign the whole damn thing to the metal shredder.

speaker: TECH
line: We'll do what we can, sir.

speaker: PETERSON
line: I'm going to figure this thing out if it kills me.
